Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Nano-Biosensing Program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET), Professors Isiah Warner, Daniel Hayes, and Francisco Hung at Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College and their groups will optimize development of novel nanomaterials derived from a group of uniform materials based on organic salts (GUMBOS). The goal of this research is to apply these nanoGUMBOS toward applications in measurement science. These materials can be developed as safe and effective alternatives to many current nanomaterials used for bioanalytical applications. This research is designed to examine the properties of nanoGUMBOS that contribute to their stability, tunability, biocompatibility, and ready applicability for use in such applications. Thus, the potential of nanoGUMBOS for employing effective combinations of properties through unique combinations of cations and anions is outlined in this proposal. As an example, a fluorescent nanoparticle may be generated from GUMBOS by use of a fluorescent dye as the cation and a traditional anion. In addition, a non-fluorescent magnetic particle may be generated by use of a non-fluorescent cation in combination with a paramagnetic anion. Obviously, multiple properties for a given nanoGUMBOS can be achieved through a combination of similar strategies. Such particles would then have uniform multiple functionalities and thus realize the full potential of nanomaterials in terms of maximum surface activity per given surface to volume ratio. This is in contrast to many nanoparticles where multiple functionalities are generated by independently injecting species with these properties into a neutral species such as silica.

Professor Warner and his team have been actively involved in educational strategies for using research and mentoring as tools to actively engage undergraduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education. They will continue their efforts in engaging undergraduate and graduate students of diverse backgrounds in this grant.

Performance_Institution.Name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involves synthesis of novel ionic compounds, formed by use of bulky organic cations and organic or inorganic counter-anions. These compounds have a variety of applications in many areas. Ionic Liquids (ILs) are often defined as organic salts with melting points less than 100 °C.  Our compounds are solid state analogues termed a Group of Uniform Materials Based on Organic Salts (GUMBOS) with melting points between 25 °C and 250 °C. Both ILs and GUMBOS can be synthesized using various combinations of cations and anions to produce structural variations that allow tuning of particular properties for specific applications.

Develop new chemotherapeutic agents: rhodamine and IR-780 based nanoGUMBOS. Cancer often leads to formation of tumors that are benign or malignant. While, chemotherapy is the most commonly used treatment, no single cure exists. However, several side effects are associated with chemotherapy due to the high toxicity and low selectivity of most chemotherapeutic agents. It is important to develop new drugs with higher selectivity and lower cytotoxicity toward normal tissues.

Rhodamine and IR-780 dyes are proven anti-cancer agents. However, these drugs have also shown extreme toxicity toward normal cells. Our study explores the chemistry of these dyes in the form of GUMBOS for enhanced selectivity toward cancer cells and lower toxicity toward normal cells. For this reason, GUMBOS and nanoGUMBOS were synthetized in order to examine and compare their efficacy, cytotoxicity, and selectivity relative to parent dyes. GUMBOS were synthetized using an anion exchange reaction employing bulky hydrophobic organic counter anions to achieve greater hydrophobicity. Using these GUMBOS, nanoparticles were synthetized using a reprecipitation method in aqueous media and ultra-sonication.

Using in-vitro studies, we have observed that rhodamine nanoGUMBOS are non-toxic toward normal cells. However, the parent dye has an IC50 of 65 µM when tested under similar conditions. Thus, nanoGUMBOS are found to be toxic to cancer cells, but non-toxic to normal cells. In addition, for all synthetized IR-780 nanoGUMBOS a dose-dependent inhibition toward breast cancer cell proliferation was observed, while only a minor impact on the viability of normal breast cells was detected with concentrations of nanoparticles up to 12.5 mM. When compared with the parent IR780 nanoparticles, all nanoGUMBOS displayed enhanced toxicity toward breast cancer cells relative to normal cells. The aggregate of these observations demonstrates that a simple counter-ion variation can be used to enhance in-vitro chemotherapeutic effects.

Synthesis of dyes based GUMBOS to improve the efficacy of Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells (DSSCs). DSSCs are of great interest because they are environmentally friendly and can be manufactured in large-scales at a lower cost than inorganic cells. To date maximum efficiency for such cells is ~11% as compared to >20% for silica based devices. Consequently, there has been growing interest to create better photosensitizing dyes, as well as other strategies for improved efficiencies of DSSCs.

In this project, ruthenium-based GUMBOS were synthesized, characterized, and investigated for applications as photosensitizing dyes. These GUMBOS showed better absorbance and fluorescence as compared to parent dyes. Thus, counter-anion variation plays a major role in enhancement of DSSC properties.

We have also studied rhodamine- and porphyrin-based GUMBOS as potential energy relay dyes (ERDs) for DSSCs. We have found that these ERDs based GUMBOS represent increased solubility in the electrolyte solvent, as compared to respective parent dyes. Similarly, GUMBOS also had enhanced spectroscopic and luminescent properties for DSSC applications. When evaluated in tandem with N719 as a photosensitizing dye, these GUMBOS provided improved solar conversion efficiencies. Manuscripts are in preparation on these studies.

Separation and extraction of Proteins employing GUMBOS and ILs. Extraction and separation of proteins is important to many areas of research. For example, a particular protein could be used as a marker to detect a particular disease or to study drug-protein interactions.

In this project, ILs were employed to optimize the separation of proteins through use of two-dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (2D-PAGE). Three different IL surfactants (ILS) were synthetized and employed to replace conventional surfactants such as sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS). A complex mixture of proteins was separated using 2D-PAGE employing synthetized ILS and compared with methods using SDS. We were able to distinguish more proteins using ILS than using SDS in conventional protocol. A manuscript has been published on this study.

Another project involves synthesis of magnetic nanoGUMBOS for solid-phase extraction of proteins that contain heme groups, e.g. hemoglobin and cytochrome C. By use of magnetic nanoGUMBOS, we were able to selectively extract heme proteins from solution media, containing other proteins. A manuscript is in preparation on this study.

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2018
Modified by: Isiah M Warner
